title-group.article-title: NaGa3Se5: An Infrared Nonlinear Optical Material with Balanced Performance Contributed by Complex {[Ga3Se5]−}∞ Anionic Network

contrib-group.aff: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, 38043 Yangzhou University , Yangzhou 225002, P. R. China

abstract.p: Second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials are extensively applied in laser-related techniques. For developing IR NLO materials, chalcogenides are the main candidates. Here, NaGa3Se5 was explored as inspired by its unique anionic structure. It crystallizes with the orthorhombic chiral P212121 structure, featuring 12 types of GaSe4 tetrahedra built into a three-dimensional {[Ga3Se5]−}∞ anionic network, representing a new NLO-functional motif. NaGa3Se5 exhibits large and phase-matchable NLO response 1.37 × AgGaS2. It has the largest band gap among the noncentrosymmetric A–MIII–Se (A = alkali metal; M = Ga, In) compounds. The NLO properties’ origin is explored via theoretical analysis. The success of NaGa3Se5 contributes a practical case for exploring new NLO materials.

NaGa3Se5 with unique complex anionic structure exhibits the largest NLO response among the ternary A−MIII−Q (A = alkali metal; MIII = Ga, In; Q = S, Se, Te) system and high LIDT, as well as wide IR transparency, simple chemical composition, and facile synthesis, giving it a novel competitive IR NLO material. This work can evoke much interest in rarely studied A−MIII−Q systems as potential IR NLO candidates.

body.p: Second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials can extend laser wavelengths via a double-frequency ability and are thus receiving increasing attention. The NLO materials in the UV, vis, and near-IR regions have been developed well, and a series of benchmark materials can basically satisfy the application requirements. However, the middle-infrared (MIR) ones are being developed because of the commercial ones’ disadvantages. Therefore, greater interest is being attracted for academic and industrial communities to explore new competitors. The most successful MIR NLO materials are diamond-like (DL) AgGaS2 (AGS), AgGaSe2 (AGSe), and ZnGeP2 (ZGP). Regretfully, their low laser-induced damage thresholds (LIDTs) or double-photon absorption heavily restrict their applications. Therefore, it is reasonable to explore new ones. Actually, there are already many studied DL chalcogenides, like M2Se3 (M = Ga, In), α-Li2ZnGeS4, Li4MgGe2S7, and (Li1.44Ag0.56)­In2SiS6, indicating DL chalcogenides with high promise as MIR NLO candidates. It is commonly believed that MQ4 (M = Ga, In, Si, Ge, Sn; Q = S, Se) tetrahedra contribute predominantly to their NLO behaviors.

Hitherto, various design strategies have been performed to discover new NLO materials, like mixing multiple anions and structural evolution via substitution. −
Among the diverse strategies, it is also common to derive from known benchmark ones. For example, KAg3Ga8Se14 and KAgGa6S10 could be derived via structural consideration from AGS; β-BaGa2Se4 was obtained by phase transition from BaB2O4; CsSbF2SO4 was derived from KTiOPO4. It is well-known that LiB3O5 (LBO) is one benchmark UV NLO material. To the best of our knowledge, rare chalcogenide works address close chemical relationships with LBO yet. Combining the outstanding NLO behaviors of DL chalcogenides and the scarcity of NLO chalcogenides possessing LBO-related chemical compositions, we have a strong interest in exploring AM3Q5 or BM6Q10 (A = monovalent alkali metal, Ag, Cu; B = divalent alkali-earth metal, Sn, Pb; M = Ga, In; Q = S, Se, Te) as new MIR NLO materials. By checking their structures, NaGa3Se5 attracted our interest because of its chiral structure and the unique polyanionic network. NaGa3Se5 was reported around 20 years ago. Surprisingly, there has been no followup work on it, not to mention any study of its physical properties. The structure of NaGa3Se5 features 12 kinds of GaSe4 tetrahedra constructing a 3D polyanionic network, representing a new NLO functional motif. NaGa3Se5 exhibits wonderful NLO properties. Its optical band gap is 2.62 eV, which is the largest among the noncentrosymmetric (NCS) A–M–Se (A = alkali metal; M = Ga, In) selenides, suggesting that it should exhibit a high LIDT. Its SHG responses are phase-matchable and reach 1.37 × AGS.

Brown block crystals (Figure S1) of NaGa3Se5 were synthesized via a solid-state reaction between Na, Ga, and Se elements at 800 °C with the yield above 80%. The experimental powder XRD pattern matches well with the calculated one, suggesting the picked-out sample’s purity (Figure S2). EDS analysis (Figure S3) suggests the close molar ratios of 1:3:5 for the single crystals of NaGa3Se5.

NaGa3Se5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral space group P212121 with 4 Na, 12 Ga, and 20 Se atoms in the asymmetric unit (Tables S1–S3). The structure is totally different from those for other AM3Q5 or BM6Q10 compounds (Tables S4 and S6). Most of them crystallize with NCS structures; however, only LiGa3Te5 (R32) and NaIn3Se5 (P32) were studied as NLO materials. Besides, although around 20 AM3Q5 or BM6Q10 compounds were discovered, only NaGa3Se5 crystallizes with the highly complex anionic structure. Most AM3Q5 or BM6Q10 contain fewer than 5 independent M and 5 independent Q atoms; comparatively, there are 12 Ga and 20 Se atoms in the asymmetric unit of NaGa3Se5, indicating that the latter has the lower symmetry and increased unit-cell volume. The structure of NaGa3Se5 cannot directly correlate with those of M2Se3, BaGa4Q7, NaGaQ2, and AgGaQ2 though its chemical formula could be written as NaGaSe2·Ga2Se3.

In fact, the structure description in the previous works on NaGa3Se5 is very simple. Therefore, we will describe the structure in detail, especially by correlating it with the following NLO performances. In the structure, each Ga and each Na atom are surrounded by four and six Se atoms to form a GaSe4 tetrahedron and NaSe6 octahedron with normal bond distances. As the Na–Se bond has ionicity character, the structure is mainly determined by the anion. Twelve types of GaSe4 tetrahedra with equal molar ratios are connected by sharing corners or edges to form the 3D {[Ga3Se5]−}∞ polyanionic network.

As the structure is so complex, it is necessary to decompose it into several parts to better understand it. The polyanionic network built from Ga–Se bonds can be split into three parts with the molar ratios of 1:1:1 (Figure a). Each part contains four types of Ga atoms, where part I is built by Ga(4)/Ga(6)/Ga(8)/Ga(12)­Se4 tetrahedrally constructed {[Ga8Se40/3](16/3)–}∞ layer in the ab plane via sharing edges between Ga(6)­Se4 and Ga(12)­Se4 tetrahedra, while sharing corners between the others (Figure b). There are two types of multiple rings in part I, one of which can be overlapped with the other by rotating 180° along the c-axis. Type II (Figure c) and Type III (Figure d) are chains built by Ga(2)/Ga(5)/Ga(7)/Ga(9)­Se4 and Ga(1)/Ga(3)/Ga(10)/Ga(11)­Se4 tetrahedra, respectively. In both cases, the components can be overlapped by rotating 180° along the b-axis. In type II, the {[Ga4Se20/3](8/3)–}∞ helical chain along the a-axis is composed of supertetrahedral clusters. For type III, it is also the [Ga4Se20/3](8/3)– helical chain along the a direction. Parts II and III link together to form helical chains along the c-axis.

caption.p: (a) 3D structure of NaGa3Se5 viewed along the a-axis. (b) Part I: {[Ga8Se40/3](16/3)‑}∞ layer; Part II (c) and part III (d): helical {[Ga4Se20/3](8/3)‑}∞ chains.

body.p: The structure of part I in NaGa3Se5 (Figure a) highly resembles that of the GaS4 tetrahedrally built slab (Figure b) in AGS assuming that the Ga(6) and Ga(12) atoms are the same, which is also the case for the AgS4 tetrahedrally built slab (Figure c).

caption.p: Structural relationship between part I in NaGa3Se5 and AGS. (a) Structure of part I viewed along the c direction; (b) GaS4 tetrahedra built slab in AGS; (c) AgS4 tetrahedra built slab in AGS.

body.p: The optical band gap of NaGa3Se5 is determined to be 2.62 eV (Figure a), consistent with the crystals’ brown color, and much higher than that of the benchmark AGSe. To the best of our knowledge, the band gap of NaGa3Se5 is the largest among the noncentrosymmetric A–M–Se (A = Na, K, Rb, Cs; M = Ga, In) compounds (Table S5), suggesting that it may possess an enhanced LIDT. Besides, the IR spectrum in 400–4000 cm–1 for the powder sample of NaGa3Se5 indicates that it has no obvious absorption peaks (Figure S4). Therefore, its powder sample has a transparency of 0.47–25 μm.

caption.p: (a) UV–vis-NIR diffuse reflectance spectrum of NaGa3Se5. (b) Size-dependent SHG responses of NaGa3Se5 and AGS when irradiated by a 2.1 μm laser. (c) SHG responses of NaGa3Se5 and AGS for their 200–250 μm samples.

body.p: The size-dependent SHG measurements on multicrystalline samples of NaGa3Se5 and standard AGS were performed by the modified Kurtz–Perry method under a 2.1 μm laser (Figure b). The SHG intensity increases along with the increased particle sizes and tends to be saturated, suggesting phase-matchable SHG responses. The maximum SHG intensity at 200–250 μm reaches ∼1.37 × AGS (Figure c). The birefringence Δn of NaGa3Se5 was measured to be 0.05 (Figure S5 and Table S7), within the moderate range (0.03–0.10) for phase-matchable (PM) IR NLO crystals, consistent with the experimental result. It is commonly believed that potential IR NLO materials should have the SHG responses of at least 0.5 × AGS. Therefore, the SHG response of NaGa3Se5 is large enough. To date, there are only LiGa3Te5 and NaIn3Se5 in the AM3Q5 or BM6Q10 family studied with NLO properties. However, LiGa3Te5 and NaIn3Se5 crystallize with different structures from that of NaGa3Se5. Besides, LiGa3Te5 contains the low melting point metal Li and metallic Te, which may result in synthetic difficulty. The SHG response of NaIn3Se5 is only 0.3 × AGS, much lower than that of NaGa3Se5. For other A–MIII–Q (A = alkali-metal; MIII = Ga, In; Q = S, Se, Te) members, only the theoretical NLO properties of NaGaS2 and AInS2 were studied. Compared with benchmark AGS and AGSe, their relatives, viz., ternary chalcogenides containing alkali-metal and GaQ4 tetrahedra, are far from adequately studied as far as their NLO potentials, even though the substitution of light-sensitive Ag with strong ionic alkali metals can induce enhanced LIDTs. Some strategies may be introduced to improve the SHG response of NaGa3Se5. Usually, the increase for the chemical bonds’ polarizability may improve the SHG response. Therefore, it may be workable to substitute Na with Li or Ag atoms, as the latter two can covalently bond with Se atoms. Besides, the S-analogue should exhibit a larger SHG response if it can be isostructural with NaGa3Se5.

The LIDTs of NaGa3Se5 and reference AGS for their powder samples were measured using a single-pulse method under the 1064 nm laser. The LIDT of NaGa3Se5 is around 1.67 × AGS (Table S8). It is usually considered that a larger band gap for a NLO material means a possible higher LIDT, which is consistent with the fact that NaGa3Se5 has a larger band gap of 2.62 eV than 2.56 eV of AGS. Apart from bandgap, thermal expansion anisotropy (TEA) is another important influence factor for LIDT. NLO materials with smaller TEA values can sustain greater thermal shock produced by a laser beam and produce higher LIDT. The temperature-dependent lattice parameters of NaGa3Se5 from 100 to 400 K were measured. The TEA of NaGa3Se5 is calculated to be 1.83 (Figure S6 and Table S9), smaller than 2.97 of AGS, suggesting that NaGa3Se5 should have a higher LIDT than that of AGS.

The band structure, density of states (DOS), and optical properties of NaGa3Se5 were calculated based on density functional theory. The band structure suggests a direct band gap of 1.76 eV as both the top of the valence band and the bottom of the conduction band locate at the G point (Figure a). As indicated in the DOS curves (Figure b), the valence band close to the Fermi level originates from the Se 4p orbital, and the conduction band near the Fermi level are contributed from Se 4s, Se 4p, and Ga 4s states, meaning that the electron transition is mainly determined by the valence orbitals of Ga and Se atoms, namely, GaSe4 tetrahedra, and has almost no relationship with Na atoms.

According to Kleinman’s symmetry rule, NaGa3Se5 has three independent SHG tensors (χ14, χ25, and χ36). At 0.59 eV, they are calculated to be 13.16, 13.12, and 13.21 pm/V (Figure c), respectively, indicating that the corresponding NLO coefficients d 14, d 25, and d 36 are 6.58, 6.56, and 6.61 pm/V, which are smaller than the experimental 13.7 pm/V for AGS. This phenomenon may be caused by the difference between calculation model and real crystals, together with the complex polyanionic network of NaGa3Se5. The theoretical birefringence of NaGa3Se5 was calculated to be 0.04 at 2.1 μm (Figure d), close to the experimental 0.05, and within the range of 0.03–0.1, a moderate value for realizing phase-matching. To better understand the origin of the NLO effect, the dipole moments of the three parts and their sum (anionic part) in one unit cell were calculated (Figure S7). Among the three parts, part III makes the predominant contribution (22.64 D) over 4.38 and 7.82 D for part I and part II, respectively, when considering the sum dipole moment of 22.52 D.

In summary, ternary selenide NaGa3Se5 with a complex anionic network is investigated by focusing on the NLO properties. It was explored because of its chemical similarity with famous LBO and the classical NLO functional motif MQ4 tetrahedron in its structure, which solely constructs the anionic component. It exhibits nice NLO activity as a strongly competitive MIR candidate, including large phase-matchable SHG response, large band gap and enhanced LIDT, and wide IR transparency. Besides, the simple chemical composition and facile synthesis make it more promising. It represents a new type of NLO material, and {[Ga3Se5]−}∞ represents a new kind of NLO functional motif. This work will stimulate more interest in the veiled A–M–Se (A = alkali metal; M = Ga, In) family. The exploration strategy for new NLO materials in this work may be introduced to discover more high-performance ones.
